Award.AwardTitle: BPE Symposia/Travel: Funding Women Engineers to Attend the National LATTICE Symposia

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Extant scientific literature indicates that women students in STEM, who take classes from women STEM faculty, are more likely to major in STEM disciplines. Therefore, engineering and science benefit from diversity. In 2015, the NSF ADVANCE Program awarded a grant (HRD-1500310) to the University of Washington, North Carolina State University, and California Polytechnic State University to create LATTICE (Launching Academics on the Tenure Track: an Intentional Community in Engineering), an adaptation of an existing professional development model that combines a national symposium with peer mentoring circles to broaden the participation of women in engineering, particularly at the underserved postdoctoral and early-career faculty stage. The intent of this travel grant is to support 30 early-career women in electrical engineering and computer science to attend the first LATTICE Symposium on May 18-21, 2017, outside of Seattle, Washington.

LATTICE intends to bring together engineering faculty, faculty diversity advocates and practitioners, and social scientists to create a professional development symposia, followed by peer Mentoring Circles for two national cohorts of early-career women interested in engineering faculty careers, to support women engineering faculty in electrical engineering and computer science and study what contributes to the success of the planning team and the intervention. The symposia, plus Mentoring Circles intervention, are designed to positively impact engineering women faculty's career self-efficacy, sense of belonging, and career advancing behaviors so that they are able to cultivate successful careers. The LATTICE project is also designed to obtain important information that can help the fields of electrical engineering and computer science better understand the efficacy of adapting the professional development model to different populations, such as women in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Launching Academics on the Tenure-Track: an Intentional Community in Engineering (LATTICE), a joint effort between the University of Washington, North Carolina State University, and California Polytechnic State University, is a national program to advance faculty diversity in engineering. LATTICE includes a professional development intervention and a research study to understand why the intervention works. 

LATTICE seeks to positively impact early-career women in Engineering who are interested in faculty careers. The LATTICE program had two cohorts. The first cohort included early-career women in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS). The second cohort was early-career underrepresented minority women in Engineering. LATTICE participants gained a stronger sense of career self-efficacy and sense of belonging through a combination of symposia, peer networks, and other support structures. The long-term goal of LATTICE is to help diversify the national engineering faculty population.

The first LATTICE symposium was held May 18-21, 2017, while the second LATTICE symposium was held May 30 - June 2, 2019. The first LATTICE symposium had 30 women from EECS and the second LATTICE symposium had 32 URM women in all fields of engineering.  Each LATTICE symposium lasted four days and addressed topics such as getting the mentoring you need to succeed, establishing an independent research program, mastering teaching, navigating organizations and tenure, taking care of me in #MeToo (gender and sexual harassment), exploring time and life management, etc. 

Following the national symposium, the early-career participants assembled into peer mentoring groups, called LATTICE Mentoring Circles. These groups are self-sustaining peer problem solving groups that meet regularly. During the Mentoring Circle meeting, each participant discusses a specific issue on which they would like to get feedback and advice. The other members of the group ask questions to better understand the issue and provide feedback and perspective.  Each participant leaves the meeting with a contract that is a concise objective specific to their issue that will help them make progress.

This travel supplement supported travel to both symposia for LATTICE participants and panelists.
